docs.lead_paragraph: Four leading childbirth specialists in Boston are challenging the Federal Government's goal to reduce the rate of Caesarean births, saying the effort could in fact be endangering some mothers and their babies. In 1990, the United States Department of Health and Human Services, concerned about unnecessary surgery and health care costs, set a goal to reduce the national Caesarean rate to 15 percent by 2000. At the time, 23.5 percent of babies were delivered by Caesarean section. The current rate hovers around 21 percent, down from a high of 25 percent in 1988 but still way above the 5 percent rate in 1970 and not likely to reach 15 percent anytime soon.

headline.main: 4 Childbirth Specialists Challenge U.S. Goal of Reducing Caesarean Births

docs.abstract: Four leading childbirth specialists in Boston are challenging Federal Government's goal to reduce rate of Caesarean births, saying effort could in fact be endangering some mothers and their babies; experts publish their views in Jan 7 issue of New England Journal of Medicine; Dr Benjamin P Sachs is chief author of journal paper; Dr Frederic Frigoletto, one of his collaborators, comments; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A Jan. 5 letter writer suggests that something be done to prevent women who take methadone from having children. Yet a Department of Health and Human Services panel concluded that methadone is the treatment of choice for heroin-addicted pregnant women because the health outcomes of both the woman and the fetus are better than they would be in the case of such addiction.
docs.abstract: National Advocates for Pregnant Women director Lynn M Paltrow reply to Jan 5 letter cites finding that methadone is treatment of choice for heroin-addicted pregnant women (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    A Jan. 5 letter writer suggests that something be done to prevent women who take methadone from having children. Yet a Department of Health and Human Services panel concluded that methadone is the treatment of choice for...

docs.lead_paragraph: The scrapbook that documents Camelia Cruz's days as a teen-age cancer patient is yellowing now, its photographs and clippings fading with time. On this sunny Monday morning, Mrs. Cruz cracked it open, as she does every now and then, unleashing a flood of memories from what seems like a former life. There she is in a wheelchair, bald and frail, her face shielded by a surgical mask, a white hospital blanket draped over her knees. There she is, smiling, her head swathed in a blue scarf beneath a sparkling tiara, on the day she was crowned Miss Periwinkle at a camp for children with cancer. There's Sandy Cuellar, her best friend from the hospital; Camelia clutched her hand as she died, at 16. Her newspaper obituary is in Mrs. Cruz's album, along with a rose petal from the funeral.

headline.main: Childhood Cancer Patients Find Survival Has Price

docs.abstract: More and more children are surviving cancer, but survival comes at a heavy price; many survivors have health problems caused by their radiation and chemotherapy, including heart, lung and kidney dysfunction, memory loss, infertility and even second cancers; added to this are social difficulties, from awkwardness in dating to difficulty finding jobs and health insurance; Camila Cruz of Baytown, Tex, describes her triumph over osteosarcoma as a teen-ager and its lingering aftermath; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The scrapbook that documents Camelia Cruz's days as a teen-age cancer patient is yellowing now, its photographs and clippings fading with  time. On this sunny Monday morning, Mrs. Cruz cracked it open, as she does every now and then, unleashing a...

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST year, when the hot flashes hit and her hormones took a nose dive, Janet Brown, 50, became a self-described raging bull. ''I was hot, cranky, impossible to live with, angry in my own body and looking for love in all the wrong places,'' said Ms. Brown, who owns a high-end designer boutique in Port Washington, N.Y. ''Not one person could be near me. I could alienate a planet.'' Her doctor referred her to Dr. Patricia Allen, an obstetrician and gynecologist with a reputation for taming the most unruly patients. ''Dr. Allen came along, otherwise known as the Elmer Gantry of medicine, and made me lose 25 pounds, take medication and see specialists for everything to get my body back into good health after seven years of neglect,'' Ms. Brown said. ''I don't perspire anymore. I am absolutely the most amiable 50-year-old in the world. I was born again.''

headline.main: GURU: Dr. Patricia Allen; The 'Small Town' Doctor Whose Lab Coat Is by Chanel

docs.abstract: Article on Manhattan Dr Patricia Allen's unique treatment for menopause, which has attracted huge following; Dr Allen comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE YOUNG WOMAN ON THE TELEvision screen simply will not look up. ''When this documentary was first to the floor, ''I was having doubts about it. It was like I was trying to block out certain memories of my father, just block him out entirely.''
docs.abstract: Ellen Pall article on 'media literacy' program at Educational Video Center, which helps New York City teen-agers document their lives on camera, and discover truths about themselves along the way; photos; nonprofit organization is housed in School for the Physical City, alternative high school in Manhattan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Each day An Dun receives a dozen calls from people desperate to spill their deepest secrets, vying to have their private lives laid bare and dissected in her popular weekly newspaper column. Some have become pregnant out of wedlock. Some have been raped by their bosses. Some have been abandoned by their husbands. Others have done the ditching themselves. In conservative Chinese society, such topics are generally taboo even among close relatives and best friends, and they are certainly not mainstream media fare. But since 1996, when Ms. An started recording matter-of-factly the stories of real people caught in such predicaments, she has wowed the younger generation with her candor and helped to liberate a nation's skeletons from the closet.

headline.main: Beijing Journal; Writer Rides Dirty Laundry to the Top in China
